utterances: I don't.
I don't.
And I - you know what - I don't.
That's where you lose me, my friend.
But listen.
And I'm so on your side.
But you know what?
You go to any barbershop, I am so not alone.
I'm so not alone.
That doesn't mean you're right.
That doesn't mean…
That don't mean you're right.
That don't mean it is not valid either.
David, did Mos Def come off as slightly off?
Oh boy, I was so disappointed in him because I thought he was, I mean, one of the brightest out there, you know, in pop music.
And I have wondered whether he was like playing a role, playing a part just to be, you know, entertaining or whatever.
But I think he - I was scratching my head and was real, real disappointed.
Gina?
Farai, that was a rambling mess.
I had the misfortune of actually going back and watching the entire show.
And every time I come on this Roundtable, you guys make me listen to some foolishness (unintelligible).
And every time - last time was Akon.
I love Cornel West.
Lord knows that I do.
But please, Dr. West, go back to writing scholarly work and steer clear of Mos Def.
I mean, Farai, the editorial decision-makers in this country seem to think that there are only three black folks who have an opinion and that's Reverend Sharpton, Reverend Jackson and Oprah.
So when you get an opportunity to have an all-black panel in a mainstream setting, you would hope that they would be coherent and credible.
And that yesterday, that was just another reminder to me.
And it was on 9/11 that I actually went back and watched the show.
It was a reminder to me that national discourse over important national issues in this country are just way past poor.

Michael, is there a whole question, though, of, you know, should a rapper, no matter how intelligent on other matters, be someone who is representing the black community or should he just go on with his self and his opinions?
Well, I think, Mos Def is reflective of a lot of people who want to be seen as being able to speak on issues just beyond what they do for a living.
I mean we see this all the time with athletes who are asked of their opinions on things.
And there's no reason to believe that these people have anything intelligent to say.
But we listen to them all the time.
We give them a lot of credibility and putting them on shows like this, only adds to the confusion.

Now, you know, as a black scholar who engages in scholarship, I can't help but shake my head sometimes when I see Cornel West, the man from whom I have a tremendous amount of respect, and other black scholars who continually get -put on television and radio programs to speak their mind.
And there are others like us who had just as much to say, some of which is probably more intelligent and certainly more accessible to the masses, often get shut out.
And so what Cornel West does, particularly in - and this needs to be put in context, he is an Obama supporter.
He has endorsed Obama and is working on behalf of his election, you know.
I couldn't tell from the interview.
Well, you know, I had an opportunity to speak with him…
That was sarcasm.
(Unintelligible)
(Soundbite of laughter)
I am sorry I missed that.
But he had the chance, you know, I have the chance to speak with him after the Howard University forum.
And he's in the attack - he's in the tank for Obama big time.
And I think that that needs to be put out as well.
Gina, what about Oprah?
There has been so much talk about how she is also wholeheartedly on the Obama bandwagon.
How did you cover this and how did you look at this through your lens?
Oh, Auntie O.
I love Auntie O as well.
I posted about this on What About Our Daughters on Sunday and I encourage your listeners to go back and read that post.
I don't care how many fundraisers Auntie O throws for Obama.
I am not going to vote for Barack Obama until he clarifies some statements that he's made in the Genarlow Wilson case.
And he continues to use the term consensual sex when the state of Georgia has said that they have an age of consent and the victim in that case didn't reach it.
So I would - I'm interested to know whether or not Auntie O knows about Barack Obama's statements in the Genarlow Wilson case.
And whether or not she's talked with him about it based on her history of being an advocate for girls and women and also being a survivor of sexual abuse.

And so that - and I think people can't - Barack Obama needs to avoid this whole rock star label that people are putting on him because quite frankly for my next president, I kind of want somebody who's just dull and boring and competent.
But that rock…
You know, I don't…
That rock star thing is all he has going for.
I mean, that makes…
I wanted to ask…
That's his whole deal.
He wouldn't be in the right world now for the fact that he's a rock star.
But that's not a bad thing.
I want to go to Santa Barbara over the weekend and see if (unintelligible), you know.

Well, you know, if you - I don't know how many of you read Lance Sweet's(ph) blog post about it, but I was just like, he was just so enraptured that there was - there was a miniature burger bar and he just talked about all of the food and all of the wonderful things.
And the problem is we saw what Howard Dean what happens when we have a rock star.
But when people have to trudge in the cold in Iowa and New Hampshire and pull the lever, they're not - that's great if we love him.
But I think most people take their choice for a president of the United States more seriously than mainstream media gives us credit for and for all those people - go ahead.
No, no. I just want to get David in on a whole youth-voting angle.
The rock star angle, which you say you like, a lot of young people I just think of P.
Diddy, all of the flood of attention around what Russell and P.
Diddy did.
Obama is a very different kind of rock star, but does that energy, you think, bring in people who may not vote otherwise?
Oh, I think it can't help but - I mean, if it's just stimulating people, if it's stimulating bloggers - he's all over YouTube.
I mean, they all try to be but he was the only one.
And Mos Def was wrong about this when he said he didn't hear Obama say anything about Katrina.
On the anniversary of Katrina, Obama was the only one who put up a video on YouTube that day with him in New Orleans and it was a beautifully produced seven-minute piece, you know.
So - you didn't think so?
Well, it's not that I didn't…
I mean, my…
…think it was a beautifully produced piece.
I'm just saying what does that have to do with Obama's position with regard to New Orleans?
I mean, John Edwards, for example, has been all over this and spoken out more forcefully on it, going back even farther than Obama.
It's not to say Obama's not going to do anything about it.
He's going to do what he can.
But I just - I'm just sort of concerned.
I don't share Mos Def's reticence about Barack Obama.
But I do think we need to be careful not to excite(ph) this guy and make him out to be more than he could possibly live up to.
We're going to move on to the N-word debate last weekend.
Comedian Eddie Griffin was yanked off the stage at the Black Enterprise Convention in Miami after he repeatedly used the N-word and other profanities during his act.
And the blogosphere has jumped all over this one, comparing it to Michael Richards.
Now, here is the thing, David.
Is there are a double standard, or should there be a double standard where black folks can use this word and white folks can't?
In this case, it was black folks yanking a black man off the stage.
What do you think of that?
Well, I'm a big comedy fan.
And I'm kind of also - believe almost anything goes.
It kind of depends on the context.
I saw Lisa Lampanelli who does some of the most…
Okay.
…harsh, racial comedy.
But in the context, she brings black people, gays, Asians, Hispanics - you see her audience is the most diverse, you know, audience in America.
And she's insulting the hell out of everybody because it's done in a certain spirit.
So I think the words - I've always thought the words aren't the problem.
It's the spirit that…
Yeah.
…that we should be worried about.
Yeah, but this was no mainstream audience.
This was Black Enterprise magazine in their golf tournament and their poo-poo chi-chi affair that they decided that they were going to have Eddie Griffin as their entertainment.
What were they thinking?
It was like them trying to juggle rattlesnakes while blindfolded, riding a unicycle.
(Soundbite of laughter)
